questions.text: There's a traditional saying in Britain 'to spend a penny' when one visits a public washroom or lavatory. What was the original cost of 'spending a penny'?
questions.explanation:
One penny.

	In 2002 the typical charge was in Britain was 20p - that is twenty *new* pence, equivalent to 48 pre-decimal pence ... That's inflation on a quite a scale!

questions.text: King John of England decreed that the holder of which post must be seen by Londoners?
questions.explanation:
The Lord Mayor of London.

	Hence the annual Lord Mayor's Parade in London.

William the Conqueror.

	The Battle of Hastings followed quickly thereafter.

questions.text: The Netherlands invited who to be their Queen, in 1575?
questions.explanation:
Elizabeth I of England.

	She declined.

questions.text: During WWI who or what was Big Bertha?
questions.explanation:
A long range gun.

	Big Bertha was used to shell Paris from behind German lines.

questions.text: Who was killed commanding the British forces that captured Quebec in 1759?
questions.explanation:
James Wolfe.

	James Wolfe was a British general 1727-1759 and took Louisbourg and Quebec during the French and Indian War.

questions.text: Which French King, fleeing Paris, was recognized by an innkeeper when he paid for a meal with a coin bearing his own likeness?
questions.explanation:
Louis XVI.

	Louis XVI was the king who lost his throne to the French Revolution and his head to the guillotine.

questions.text: Which craft first crossed the English Channel in 1959?
questions.explanation:
The Hovercraft.

	A Hovercraft can carry 30 automobiles and up to 250 passengers.

questions.text: At which battle did Lord Nelson die?
questions.explanation:
Trafalgar.

	The battle at Trafalgar broke the back of the French Navy and established British superiority at sea.

questions.text: Which Home Secretary did the English newspaper the 'Daily Mirror' describe as Mrs Thatcher's 'house trained poodle' ?
questions.explanation:
Leon Brittain.

	Who let the dogs out?
